awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Sustainable Nanotechnology (CSN) enables fundamental studies of the specific molecular interactions expected to occur when the surfaces of engineered nanoparticles come into contact with biological interfaces and components. The chemical insight gained from molecular and mechanistic studies of nano-bio interactions is used to intentionally design nanomaterials that provide the desired technical functions while also minimizing potentially adverse consequences with the environment. CSN research leads to introduction of a new generation of safer nanomaterials that may impact multiple sectors of the economy including energy, transportation, electronics, food, and agriculture. The CSN prepares a new generation of scientific innovators by providing education and professional development opportunities focused on innovation, communication, leadership, and interdisciplinary scientific skills. CSN researchers actively encourage diversity within chemistry through CSN-run workshops on overcoming implicit bias, recruitment of graduate students and postdocs, and Center-sponsored research experiences for students and faculty from underrepresented groups as well as veteran undergraduates. CSN researchers encourage diversity in public engagement, develops and practices informal communication skills, and expands the highly successful sustainable-nano.com blog to include Spanish language content, K-12 activity materials, podcasts, and videos.

CSN integrates experiments with computation in three integrated research focus areas (RFAs). RFA1 develops new materials with precisely controlled structure and properties, molecular-level characterization tools such as advanced non-linear optical methods and sub-diffraction imaging, and novel computational methods spanning length scales from nanometers to millimeters. RFA2 uses the RFA1 tool kit to understand, control, and predict how nanomaterials attach to, penetrate, and alter cell surfaces using lipid bilayers as model systems for cell membranes. RFA3 determines the molecular processes by which pristine and environmentally transformed nanomaterials interact with living systems with diverse cellular chemistries, ranging from single cell to multi-cellular organisms. The integration of these three RFAs enables the Center to establish how nanomaterial properties and behavior impact biological outcomes. This knowledge leads to reliable predictions of biological responses to existing and future nanomaterials and guides the design and synthesis of safe, sustainable nanomaterials. In pursuing the project goals, the CSN puts particular emphasis on the synthesis, characterization, and molecular-level interactions initiated by complex, composite nanomaterials that are being used in emerging and future nano-enabled commercial technologies.

The Center for Sustainable Nanotechnology is funded as part of the Centers for Chemical Innovation (CCI) program.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Nanomaterials are increasingly used for technologies such as catalysis, energy storage, water purification, photochemical generation of solar fuels, and crop protection. Research in the Center for Sustainable Nanotechnology (CSN) was motivated by a limited understanding of how the unique chemical and physical properties of technologically relevant nanoparticles determine their environmental and biological interactions. Experimental and theoretical studies in the CSN provided a molecular-level understanding of nanomaterial properties, their aqueous transformations, and their underlying chemical interactions with living systems to enable the development of emerging nanotechnologies in a sustainable manner for societal benefit. CSN researchers used a chemistry-centered approach that tightly integrated nanomaterial synthesis, hypothesis-driven investigation of nanomaterial transformations and biological interactions, development and implementation of new tools for characterizing nanomaterial and biological interfaces at a molecular level, and integrated computational methods to understand, predict, and control nanomaterial properties. This Make, Measure, Model paradigm established new innovation through the synthesis and functionalization of next-generation nanoparticles and has the potential for societal impact by informing environmental protection strategies and enabling new technologies, such as nano-enabled sustainable food production.

-

Intellectual Merit. The CSN utilized a chemistry-centered approach for enhancing environmental sustainability that leveraged synthesis and characterization expertise to understand and control nanoparticle compositions, surface chemistries, chemical transformations, and biological interactions. A cornerstone of the CSN approach also included the development of advanced analytical and computational tools and methodologies to investigate nanomaterial chemistry and chemical transformations in increasingly complex environmental and biological systems, such as advanced model membrane platforms, super-resolution and correlated imaging techniques, -omics approaches, and through the synthesis and functionalization of nanoparticles with unique optical properties. These synthesis, characterization, and computational capabilities enabled CSN researchers to correlate nanoparticle properties to molecular-level changes in chemistry of life processes for broad classes of organisms, such as nanoparticle-induced oxidation-reduction mechanisms that alter heme synthesis pathways essential for hemoglobin production. CSN studies also identified structure-function relationships underlying nanoparticle interactions with biological systems that enabled redesign strategies, and researchers demonstrated the impact of this compositional tuning approach by predicting and then synthesizing industrially relevant nanoparticle compositions that reduced their adverse biological impacts. Finally, tight integration of experiment and theory identified new nanomaterial formulations with beneficial properties for enhancing environmental sustainability, such as compositions that incorporated less toxic and/or more Earth-abundant elements (e.g., complex metal oxides, Cd-free quantum dots, polymeric carbon dots) and strategies that leveraged our understanding of chemical transformation mechanisms to improve the efficiency of micronutrient delivery to crops (e.g., Cu oxides and phosphates, mesoporous silica).  

-

The CSN has had transformative impact on the chemistry community by integrating computational and analytical methodologies to enable molecular-level studies of dynamic systems that traditionally have not been explored by chemists due to their chemical complexity. These studies have provided new and often unexpected insights into nanomaterials properties, their transformations in chemically complex surroundings, and mechanisms underlying nanoparticle interactions with cells and organisms. For example, CSN researchers established chemical principles for understanding, predicting, and controlling the properties and aqueous transformations of emerging nanomaterials with complex and chemically reactive compositions (e.g., battery cathode materials). CSN researchers demonstrated how molecular structure and spatial organization of chemical species at nanomaterial surfaces play surprisingly important and complex roles in controlling the presentation of charged groups, nanoparticle aggregation, acquisition of molecular coatings (or coronas) in aqueous environments, and interactions with biological surfaces. A deeper understanding of the chemical processes that mediate nanomaterial interactions with cells and organisms also uncovered possible unifying molecular mechanisms for predicting biological impact of technologically relevant metal oxide nanomaterials. The CSN developed new optically active nanomaterials and state-of-the-art imaging approaches to understand how nanoparticle interact with biological surfaces (or biointerfaces) and alter biochemical pathways in living cells and organisms at the level of single-particles and single-cells . These and other experimental and computational tools developed by CSN researchers can be applied broadly across the field of chemistry to understand dynamic and heterogeneous materials properties in chemically complex environments. 

-

Broader Impacts. CSN Broader Impact include our Sustainable Nano Blog and podcasts (https://sustainable-nano.com), professional development and mentoring programs for students and postdocs, and an Innovation portfolio that includes collaborations with industry partners, generation of intellectual property, and a spinoff company (Ecofriendly Plastics) based on center research. Importantly, a cornerstone of CSN success was our Broadening Participation efforts, which includes Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) and Research Experience for Veterans (REV) programs that supported >50 undergraduate researchers over the last five years and outreach effort such as Nano at Home (https://susnano.wisc.edu/nanoathome), a student-led effort to provide nano-related chemistry demonstrations that members of the public can conduct safely and easily at home. From the beginning, the CSN emphasized creating a welcoming climate that embraces scientists with diverse identities and cultural backgrounds, and creating community within our center was an essential component of our success.


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Robert Hamers

Image
  • Experimental and theoretical studies in the CSN provided molecular-level understanding of nanomaterial properties, their aqueous transformations, and their underlying chemical interactions with living systems.
    Dr. Zachary Jones, Dr. Caley Allen, Dr. Jaya Borgatta, Dr. Yi Cui, Dr. Bo Zhi, Prof. Qiang Cui, Prof. Robert Hamers
    Copyrighted
    Robert Hamers
    Make, Measure, Model: Towards enabling new sustainable nanotechnologies
